verses.text: Finally, brothers, pray for us, so that the word of the Lord may run swiftly and be honored, just as it did with you.
verses.comment: Paul often asked for prayer, linking the mission of preaching to the church's intercession (see Col. 4:3). The phrase 'run swiftly' emphasizes the urgency and spread of the Gospel in Acts.

verses.text: And that we may be delivered from unreasonable and evil people, for not all have faith.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges opposition and spiritual warfare, highlighting the reality of faith clashing with the world's unbelief (cf. Rom. 15:31).

verses.text: But the Lord is faithful, and He will establish you and guard you from the evil one.
verses.comment: 'The evil one' can reference Satan (Matt. 6:13), showing the Lord's protection. The concept of being established points to perseverance in the faith.

verses.text: We have confidence in the Lord concerning you, that you are doing and will continue to do the things we command.
verses.comment: 'Commands' refers to apostolic teaching with divine authority, safeguarding doctrinal continuity (see 2 Thess. 2:15).

verses.text: And may the Lord direct your hearts into the love of God and into the steadfastness of Christ.
verses.comment: Christ's perseverance is held as the model for believers, showing both a literal encouragement and a spiritual participation in Christ's endurance.

verses.text: Now we command you, brothers, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you keep away from any brother who walks disorderly and not according to the tradition that you received from us.
verses.comment: Here, 'tradition' indicates not only teaching but also a way of life passed on by the apostles, showing apostolic authority and order (cf. 1 Cor. 5:11).

verses.text: For you yourselves know how you ought to imitate us, because we were not idle among you.
verses.comment: 'Imitate us' reinforces the example set by Paul and companions, underlining the importance of living tradition in the church.

verses.text: Nor did we eat anyone’s bread without paying for it, but with labor and toil we worked night and day, so that we might not be a burden to any of you.
verses.comment: Paul defended his right to support but declined it, modeling self-sacrifice and humility in leadership.

verses.text: Not because we do not have the right, but in order to give you in ourselves an example to imitate.
verses.comment: Paul upholds both Apostolic rights and the value of personal example, linking the minister's life to the teaching given.

verses.text: For even when we were with you, we gave you this rule: 'If anyone is not willing to work, neither let him eat.'
verses.comment: The work ethic is rooted in creation's order (Gen. 3:19) and wisdom literature, and is presented as a command for the Christian community.

verses.text: For we hear that some among you are walking in idleness, not busy at work but busybodies.
verses.comment: Warns against disorder within the church—the early church placed communal order and discipline as essential for unity.

verses.text: Now such people we command and urge in the Lord Jesus Christ to work quietly and earn their own bread.
verses.comment: Quiet, hard work is part of the Christian witness. The command is given in the name of Christ, showing His ongoing authority in the church's discipline.

verses.text: But as for you, brothers, do not grow weary in doing good.
verses.comment: 'Doing good' refers to all acts of charity and perseverance in virtue, central to Christian communal life.

verses.text: If anyone does not obey our instruction in this letter, take note of that person and do not associate with him, so that he may be ashamed.
verses.comment: Separation is for correction and restoration, highlighting church discipline's role in maintaining holiness (cf. Matt. 18:17).

verses.text: Yet do not regard him as an enemy, but warn him as a brother.
verses.comment: Correction is given in charity, aiming for repentance and restoration (see Gal. 6:1 for a similar approach).

verses.text: Now may the Lord of peace Himself give you peace at all times in every way. The Lord be with you all.
verses.comment: Paul echoes Christ's blessing of peace (John 14:27), placing trust in the continued spiritual presence of the Lord among the church.

verses.text: I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand. This is the sign of genuineness in every letter; this is how I write.
verses.comment: Paul’s handwritten signature verified authenticity and apostolic authority, showing early church concerns about genuine teaching and leadership.

verses.text: The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all.
verses.comment: Paul’s closing formula invokes Christ’s grace—key for living the Christian life, receiving both faith and strength through Him.
